comment._content: The Fine Arts Building is the only building remaining from the fair (that I know of).  It now houses the Museum of Science and Industry (http://www.msichicago.org).

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: The source website of the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago contains a view and the following quote confirm researcher Stefanie’s comment: “A walking tour that will take you both in and outside the Museum as well as back in time to its origins as the Palace of Fine Arts for the 1893 World’s Fair.”  Thanks, stefanie!

comment.author: 8398936@N06
comment._content: From 1894-1920 this building was home to the Field Museum. The Field relocated to its current location in Grant Park and the building sat empty and deteriorating for years until it reopened as the Museum of Science and Industry in 1933, in time for the Century of Progress World's Fair held that year.

comment._content: Here is a shot from late 2008. The Museum of Science and Industry was my favorite place to visit when I was a kid. My parents took me and my brother every year.

comment.author: 95175539@N00
comment._content: What's incredible is that the Museum of Science and Industry is so vast on its own. Just trying to imagine the scale of the World's Fair -- and the fact that it was built in just a few years -- is mind-blowing.

comment.author: 84391174@N07
comment._content:
I read "The Devil in the White City" for our selected book in our monthly book club.  I am hosting the discussion and wanted to see photos of some of the World's Fair buildings.  I also previously taught middle school science in Glenwood, IL, and often took my students to the Museum of Science and Industry as well as the Field Museum and the Adler Planetarium--all buildings that had their advent during the Chicago World's Fair.
Diane Harrison

comment._content: Actually it's not the only building, there is the Art Institution of Chicago that was also built for the fair of 1893.
